Personalized Federated Learning of Probabilistic Models: A PAC-Bayesian Approach

Mahrokh Ghoddousi Boroujeni1, Andreas Krause2, and Giancarlo Ferrari Trecate1
1 Institute of Mechanical Engineering, EPFL, Switzerland
{mahrokh.ghoddousiboroujeni, giancarlo.ferraritrecate}@epfl.ch
2 Department of Computer Science, ETH Zürich, Switzerland
krausea@ethz.ch
Abstract

Federated learning aims to infer a shared model from private and decentralized data stored locally by multiple clients. Personalized federated learning (PFL) goes one step further by adapting the global model to each client, enhancing the model’s fit for different clients. A significant level of personalization is required for highly heterogeneous clients, but can be challenging to achieve especially when they have small datasets. To address this problem, we propose a PFL algorithm named PAC-PFL for learning probabilistic models within a PAC-Bayesian framework that utilizes differential privacy to handle data-dependent priors. Our algorithm collaboratively learns a shared hyper-posterior and regards each client’s posterior inference as the personalization step. By establishing and minimizing a generalization bound on the average true risk of clients, PAC-PFL effectively combats over-fitting. PAC-PFL achieves accurate and well-calibrated predictions, supported by experiments on a dataset of photovoltaic panel power generation, FEMNIST dataset [Caldas et al., 2019], and Dirichlet-partitioned EMNIST dataset [Cohen et al., 2017].

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) aims at collaboratively learning from multiple private datasets stored by end-devices, called clients [Konečný et al., 2015]. The main line of FL iteratively trains a global model that performs well for all clients. A trusted server orchestrates the training by sending the model to a subset of the clients at each iteration and collecting model updates from them. The server prepares the model for the next iteration by aggregating these local updates. The server only accesses the communicated model updates and not the clients’ datasets. Thus, FL offers better data privacy and lowers communication than a data-centric approach, where all clients’ datasets are sent to the server.

A defining characteristic of FL is that the clients’ data are potentially heterogeneous [Kairouz et al., 2021, Li et al., 2020a]. This violates the critical i.i.d samples assumption in training a single global model, leading to convergence issues or poor performance [Li et al., 2020b]. Personalized FL (PFL) addresses this challenge by incorporating a further personalization step of adapting the global model to each client’s data. While PFL has been extensively studied, the following challenges (c111-c444) remain less explored. First, (c111) the majority of PFL approaches yield point estimates of the models, limiting their ability to quantify epistemic uncertainty, which is problematic in safety-critical applications [Guo et al., 2017, Achituve et al., 2021]. Second, (c222) the resulting personalized models remain closely tied and are not fully capable of capturing highly heterogeneous, multimodal scenarios. Third, (c333) many proposed methods suffer from performance degradation when clients’ datasets are small. Finally, (c444) most approaches do not take into account the collection of new data over time. In this paper, we propose a PFL algorithm, called PAC-PFL, for tackling the challenges outlined above, (c111-c444).

A natural PFL method for probabilistic models is to collaboratively learn a shared prior and regard the posterior inference as the personalization step. However, in this setting, the learned prior depends on each client’s data, conflicting with the Bayesian framework [Box and Tiao, 1992]. To overcome this, we leverage a PAC-Bayesian technique capable of handling data-dependent priors [Rivasplata et al., 2020] for inferring the posterior and providing uncertainty quantification, hence addressing (c111). However, the clients’ posterior distributions tend to resemble each other due to their connection with the shared prior, impairing the performance in heterogeneous scenarios (see c222). As an alternative, we collaboratively learn a shared distribution over priors, termed a hyper-posterior, from which the clients sample their priors to perform personalized posterior inference. By removing the linkage of the personalized posteriors to the same shared prior, this approach enhances flexibility in capturing heterogeneous patterns, thus resolving (c222).

To mitigate potential overfitting in low-data scenarios (see c333), we select the hyper-posterior by minimizing a generalization bound on clients’ true loss. Section 4 will demonstrate that this approach provides a principled regularization of the hyper-posterior, facilitating the learning of complex models without overfitting. Regarding (c444), PAC-PFL accommodates collecting new data over time. Due to practical constraints, only a fraction of clients communicate with the server in each iteration. Before reconnecting with the server, a client may collect new data that can be used for personalization, but not for training the shared hyper-posterior. In an extreme case, there may be clients joining the system later, denoted as new clients, who have never communicated with the server. The distinction between existing and new clients is important, as distinct generalization bounds hold for each group.

We evaluate our framework on Gaussian Process (GP) regression and Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) classification as representative examples of probabilistic models. Our experiments demonstrate that PAC-PFL produces accurate and well-calibrated predictions (c111) even in highly heterogeneous (c222) and data-poor (c333) scenarios. Additionally, we show that PAC-PFL enables positive transfer learning from existing clients to new clients. (c444) Finally, our method can be interpreted through Jaynes’ principle of maximum entropy [Jaynes, 1957] as explained in Appendix 8.1.

2 Related work

Meta-PFL.

PAC-PFL falls under the meta-PFL category [Kulkarni et al., 2020]. Meta-learning, developed independently of FL, involves training a global model on various related learning problems (tasks), which can be efficiently fine-tuned for a new task. The link between meta-learning and PFL was first explored in Jiang et al. [2019], where a method was proposed to simultaneously learn the global model and its personalization. Several methods aim to find a model initialization that performs well after personalization by individual clients using their respective data [Khodak et al., 2019, Fallah et al., 2020, Chen et al., 2018]. However, the approach of  Khodak et al. [2019] suffers from scalability issues due to its reliance on sequential updates from clients. On the other hand, Fallah et al. [2020] proposes an intuitive algorithm by narrowing the personalization step down to taking one or a few steps of gradient descent with respect to clients’ own data. However, the personalized models have a high resemblance to the shared model due to the personalization scheme. Additionally, all these methods are frequentist, specific to parametric models, and lack generalization bounds. For a comprehensive overview of PFL, please refer to Kulkarni et al. [2020].

FL for probabilistic models.

Several FL methods aim to learn a global posterior at the server level, which is generally intractable. Accordingly, these studies resort to approximation techniques such as Laplace approximation [Al-Shedivat et al., 2020], Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [Kassab and Simeone, 2022], and Variational Inference (VI) [Bui et al., 2018]. In Corinzia and Buhmann [2019], personalized posteriors are achieved by training global and per-client variational factors jointly, but this method faces scalability issues in systems with many clients since refining personalized models is performed sequentially. While this approach performs well in the tested scenarios, it is expected that the global variational factors cannot capture patterns among highly heterogeneous clients, and the framework becomes equivalent to clients learning solely on their local data, as emphasized by  Marfoq et al. [2021]. Recently, Zhang et al. [2022] introduced pFedBayes which is a bilevel optimization approach combining a server-level global prior with client-level personalized posteriors. In each round, clients calculate local posteriors by optimizing their data likelihood while adding regularization towards the global prior. The server calculates the prior by minimizing the average client loss. However, this approach, due to its bi-level optimization, imposes a significant computational burden. Additionally, it results in a heuristic posterior, forfeiting the Bayesian interpretation, due to the dependence of the prior on the client data. In contrast, we employ an inference framework, as proposed by Dziugaite and Roy [2018], to handle data-dependent priors. Akin to meta-PFL approaches, regularization towards a global model may limit the degree of personalization achievable.

The closest work to our approach is Achituve et al. [2021], which performs deep kernel learning for GPs by maximizing the average Log Marginal Likelihood (LML) across all clients, learning a shared prior, and regarding the posterior inference as personalization. Our method distinguishes itself from  Achituve et al. [2021] by learning a distribution over priors instead of a single prior. Moreover, while  Achituve et al. [2021] only considers zero-mean priors, our approach can learn both the mean and the covariance of the prior distribution. The reason for focusing on covariance learning and ignoring the mean in Achituve et al. [2021] may be that the LML implicitly regularizes the kernel, while the mean can quickly overfit, as suggested in Fortuin et al. [2020]. Our approach overcomes this issue by incorporating a principled regularization term.

PAC-Bayesian meta-learning

The setup described in Section 1 is closely related to meta-learning within the PAC-Bayesian framework  [Amit and Meir, 2018, Pentina and Lampert, 2014, Rothfuss et al., 2021]. In this scheme, a meta-learner is presented with a sequence of heterogeneous learning tasks and aims to learn a hyper-posterior from previous tasks to facilitate posterior inference for a new unseen task. The meta-learner achieves this by establishing and minimizing a generalization bound on the new task using the previous tasks’ data, establishing a data flow from existing to new tasks. While the mentioned approaches can be used for FL by treating each client as a task, they do not incentivize existing clients to collaborate in the scheme. In contrast, our approach focuses on the existing clients who are the primary concern of an FL system and minimizes a generalization bound on them. Particularly, our approach is an adaptation of Rothfuss et al. [2021] to PFL, where the key technical difference is dealing with data-dependent priors. Our obtained bounds are structurally similar to those of Rothfuss et al. [2021], allowing us to leverage similar methods for optimizing the hyper-posterior.

3 Preliminaries and notation

Consider n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} existing clients, each characterized by an unknown data distribution, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, that is over a support of R𝐳=R𝐱×Rysubscript𝑅𝐳subscript𝑅𝐱subscript𝑅𝑦R_{\mathbf{z}}=R_{\mathbf{x}}\times R_{y}. Every sample from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, is a pair of features, 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x}, and the corresponding target, y𝑦y, where 𝐱∈R𝐱⊂ℝd𝐱subscript𝑅𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d} and y∈Ry⊂ℝ𝑦subscript𝑅𝑦ℝy\in R_{y}\subset\mathbb{R}. The support of features and targets, R𝐱subscript𝑅𝐱R_{\mathbf{x}} and Rysubscript𝑅𝑦R_{y}, are identical among clients, and the target is assumed scalar for simplicity. Each client observes two distinct sets of mi∈ℕsubscript𝑚𝑖ℕm_{i}\in\mathbb{N} and m~i∈ℕ∪{0}subscript~𝑚𝑖ℕ0\tilde{m}_{i}\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{0\} i.i.d samples from 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, denoted by 𝒮i∼𝒟imisimilar-tosubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}} and 𝒮~i∼𝒟im~isimilar-tosubscript~𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}}. The first set, 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}, collects the samples that client i𝑖i involves in both FL and personalization steps and is non-empty. The second set, 𝒮~isubscript~𝒮𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}, consists of the samples obtained later that are used only for model personalization and may be empty. We assume that m~i≤misubscript~𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\tilde{m}_{i}\leq m_{i} for all i𝑖i, and denote the number of clients with m~i>0subscript~𝑚𝑖0\tilde{m}_{i}>0 by n2∈{0,⋯,n}subscript𝑛20⋯𝑛n_{2}\in\{0,\cdots,n\}. We allow 𝒟i≠𝒟jsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{i}\neq\mathcal{D}_{j} and mi≠mjsubscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚𝑗m_{i}\neq m_{j} to accommodate clients’ heterogeneity. Still, we consider a distribution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} over the unknown data distributions and the number of samples, (𝒟i,mi)∼𝒯similar-tosubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝒯(\mathcal{D}_{i},m_{i})\sim\mathcal{T}, to encode relatedness among clients. For notation convenience, we shall use 𝒮≔{𝒮i}i=1n≔𝒮superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{S}\coloneqq\{\mathcal{S}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, 𝒟≔{𝒟i}i=1n≔𝒟superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{D}\coloneqq\{\mathcal{D}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}, 𝐦≔[m1,⋯,mn]≔𝐦subscript𝑚1⋯subscript𝑚𝑛\mathbf{m}\coloneqq[{m_{1}},\cdots,{m_{n}}], and 𝐦~≔[m~1,⋯,m~n]≔~𝐦subscript~𝑚1⋯subscript~𝑚𝑛\mathbf{\tilde{m}}\coloneqq[{\tilde{m}_{1}},\cdots,{\tilde{m}_{n}}].

Each client i∈1,⋯,n𝑖1⋯𝑛i\in{1,\cdots,n} aims to learn a hypothesis function hi:R𝐱→Ry:subscriptℎ𝑖absent→subscript𝑅𝐱subscript𝑅𝑦h_{i}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow{}R_{y} that can be used for predicting the label y∗subscript𝑦y_{*} of an unseen input 𝐱∗subscript𝐱\mathbf{x_{*}} drawn from the unknown data distribution 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. The quality of hℎh at (𝐱∗,y∗)subscript𝐱subscript𝑦(\mathbf{x_{*}},y_{*}) is measured by a loss function which we assume to be bounded, ℓ:ℋ×R𝐳→[a,b]:ℓabsent→ℋsubscript𝑅𝐳𝑎𝑏\ell:\mathcal{H}\times R_{\mathbf{z}}\xrightarrow{}[a,b]. Since the data distribution, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, is unknown, standard methods select the best hypothesis according to the set of observed samples, 𝒮i∪𝒮~isubscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}; for instance, by minimizing the empirical risk associated with ℓℓ\ell.

Using a single hypothesis based on limited observations leads to epistemic uncertainty [Draper, 1995] and overconfident target estimation [Kass and Raftery, 1995]. To address this issue, the PAC-Bayesian framework [McAllester, 1999] places probability distributions over the hypothesis space, ℋℋ\mathcal{H}, and combines all possible hypotheses sampled from these distributions for making inferences. Two such distributions are enlisted: a prior distribution, P𝑃P, and a posterior distribution, Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i}, which depends on the prior and the observations through a mapping, Qi≔ℚ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)≔subscript𝑄𝑖ℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖Q_{i}\coloneqq\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}). While the prior and posterior terms resemble the Bayesian terminology, the posterior mapping, ℚℚ\mathds{Q}, is not (necessarily) obtained through Bayes’ theorem. Additionally, recent advances in PAC-Bayesian analysis enable employing priors that depend slightly on the data to make the learning pipeline more data-driven, which is contrary to the Bayesian formalism [Rivasplata et al., 2020].

Client-level PAC-Bayesian bounds

The flexibility in choosing the mapping ℚℚ\mathds{Q} can be exploited to achieve desired characteristics. Ideally, clients aim to choose a ℚℚ\mathds{Q} that minimizes the true risk,

ℒC​(ℚ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i),𝒟i)superscriptℒ𝐶ℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i}\big{)} ≔𝔼h∼ℚ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)𝔼𝐳∼𝒟i[ℓ​(h,𝐳)],≔absentsubscript𝔼similar-toℎℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝔼similar-to𝐳subscript𝒟𝑖ℓℎ𝐳\displaystyle\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{h\sim\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\mathbf{z}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}}\big{[}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\big{]}, (1)

where superscript C𝐶C indicates that (1) is calculated by a client. In most cases, 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} is unknown and the true loss is approximated by its empirical counterpart,

ℒ^C​(ℚ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i),𝒮i∪𝒮~i)superscript^ℒ𝐶ℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖\displaystyle\mathcal{\hat{L}}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}\big{)} ≔𝔼h∼ℚ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)[1mi+m~i​∑𝐳∈𝒮i∪𝒮~iℓ​(h,𝐳)].≔absentsubscript𝔼similar-toℎℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖subscript𝐳subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖ℓℎ𝐳\displaystyle\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{h\sim\mathds{Q}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})}\big{[}\frac{1}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}\sum_{\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\big{]}. (2)

PAC-Bayes theory [McAllester, 1999] provides a guarantee on the worst loss clients may suffer by upper bounding the unknown true risk in (1) based on the empirical risk in (2). The original PAC bound by McAllester [1999] assumes that the prior, P𝑃P, is independent of the data. However, in our setup, the prior is obtained from the FL algorithm acting on the data subset 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}, hence, is data-dependent. Dziugaite and Roy [2018] propose a recipe for adapting any PAC bound with data-free prior to a data-dependent prior that is stable to slight changes in the data, formalized by the notion of Differential Privacy (DP) defined below.

Definition 3.1 ([Dwork and Roth, 2014]).

Let ϵi∈ℝ+subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscriptℝ\epsilon_{i}\in\mathbb{R}_{+} and 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} be a randomized algorithm that takes a dataset as input and generates a stochastic output. The algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-differentially private if for all datasets 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} and 𝒮^isubscript^𝒮𝑖\hat{\mathcal{S}}_{i} that differ in a single data sample and all subsets 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O} of possible outcomes of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A},

e−ϵi​P​r​[𝒜​(𝒮i^)∈𝒪]≤P​r​[𝒜​(𝒮i)∈𝒪]≤eϵi​P​r​[𝒜​(𝒮i^)∈𝒪],superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝒜^subscript𝒮𝑖𝒪𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝒜subscript𝒮𝑖𝒪superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖𝑃𝑟delimited-[]𝒜^subscript𝒮𝑖𝒪\displaystyle e^{-\epsilon_{i}}\,Pr[\mathcal{A}(\hat{\mathcal{S}_{i}})\in\mathcal{O}]\leq Pr[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_{i})\in\mathcal{O}]\leq e^{\epsilon_{i}}\,Pr[\mathcal{A}(\hat{\mathcal{S}_{i}})\in\mathcal{O}], (3)

where the probability is taken over the randomness used by the algorithm.

Intuitively, (3) states that 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is stable w.r.t changing one sample of 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} [Dwork et al., 2015]. The parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon controls the privacy/stability level and is smaller if 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is more private/stable.

To state a PAC bound for client i𝑖i, we regard the federated pipeline as a randomized algorithm that takes 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} as input and outputs P=𝒜𝒮\𝒮i​(𝒮i)𝑃subscript𝒜\𝒮subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖P=\mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{S}\backslash\mathcal{S}_{i}}(\mathcal{S}_{i}). The subscript 𝒮\𝒮i\𝒮subscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}\backslash\mathcal{S}_{i} contains samples from all clients except i𝑖i and emphasizes that P𝑃P depends on data from other clients likewise. However, DP is only studied for the argument, 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}. Randomization in 𝒜𝒮\𝒮isubscript𝒜\𝒮subscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{A}_{\mathcal{S}\backslash\mathcal{S}_{i}} arises from sampling the prior from the hyper-posterior.

When the prior is obtained through a differentially private algorithm, we apply the method of Dziugaite and Roy [2018] on a bound due to Alquier et al. [2016] to derive the following theorem.

Remark.

The term I​(ϵi,mi,δ)𝐼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝛿I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta) is the only change from the bound of Alquier et al. [2016] with a data-free prior.

We refer to Theorem 3.1 as the client-level upper bound because it provides a guarantee on the unknown true risk of each client i𝑖i.

Optimal posterior

The bound in (4) holds for all Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} and thus can be minimized w.r.t Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} to obtain the tightest upper bound on the true risk. Since ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} only reflects through the term I𝐼I in (4), the optimal posterior is the same as the minimizer of the bound with a data-free prior derived in Catoni [2007].

Corollary 3.1.1 ([Catoni, 2007]).

Given a prior, P𝑃P, obtained through an ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-DP algorithm and observations, 𝒮i∪𝒮~isubscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}, the optimal posterior minimizing the right-hand side of (4) is a Gibbs distribution:

Qi∗≔ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)=P​(h)⋅exp⁡(−βmi+m~i​∑𝐳∈𝒮i∪𝒮~iℓ​(h,𝐳))/ZβC​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i),≔subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑖superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖⋅𝑃ℎ𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖subscript𝐳subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖ℓℎ𝐳subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖\displaystyle Q^{*}_{i}\coloneqq\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})=P(h)\cdot\exp\Bigl{(}\frac{-\beta}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}\sum_{\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\Bigr{)}/Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}), (5)

where ZβC​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)≔𝔼h∼Pexp⁡(−βmi+m~i​∑𝐳∈𝒮i∪𝒮~iℓ​(h,𝐳))≔subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝔼similar-toℎ𝑃𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖subscript𝐳subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖ℓℎ𝐳Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{h\sim P}\exp\Bigl{(}\frac{-\beta}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}\sum_{\mathbf{z}\in\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}}\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\Bigr{)} is a normalization constant.

Using the negative log-likelihood loss, ℓ​(h,𝐳)≔−ln⁡Pr⁡[𝐳|h]≔ℓℎ𝐳Prconditional𝐳ℎ\ell(h,\mathbf{z})\coloneqq-\ln\Pr[\mathbf{z}|h] and β=mi+m~i𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, reduces ZβCsubscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽Z^{C}_{\beta} to the LML and the Gibbs posterior coincides with the Bayes posterior [Guedj, 2019].

Plugging in the closed-form formula of the optimal posterior (5) into the client-level bound obtains:

ℒC​(ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i),𝒟i)≤superscriptℒ𝐶superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i}\big{)}\leq 1β​(−ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i)+β2​(b−a)28​(mi+m~i)+I​(ϵi,mi,δ)+ln⁡(1δ)),1𝛽subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖superscript𝛽2superscript𝑏𝑎28subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖𝐼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝛿1𝛿\displaystyle\frac{1}{\beta}\Big{(}-\ln{Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i})}+\frac{\beta^{2}(b-a)^{2}}{8(m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i})}+I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)+\ln{(\frac{1}{\delta})}\Big{)}, (6)

holding with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over 𝒮i∼𝒟imi,S~i∼𝒟im~iformulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖similar-tosubscript~𝑆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}},\tilde{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}}. The simplified bound (6) removes the explicit dependence on Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} and is tighter than the generic bound per (4).

In the rest of this paper, we assume that clients utilize Qi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑖Q^{*}_{i} whenever the privacy requirement of Theorem 3.1 is satisfied. This is a mild assumption bearing into mind that the family of Gibbs posteriors (for different choices of ℓℓ\ell and β𝛽\beta) encompasses the Bayes posterior.

4 Theoretical framework for PAC-Bayesian federated learning

Overview of the approach.

Having defined basic components, we reemphasize the main research problem. In this paper, we employ FL to select the prior distribution in a data-driven manner. With a similar justification of considering distributions over hypotheses, we formulate two distributions over priors: a hyper-prior, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, and a hyper-posterior, 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. The hyper-prior must be independent of observations, while the hyper-posterior depends on the observed samples by clients.

We assume the existence of a trusted server communicating with a set of existing clients, 1,⋯,n1⋯𝑛1,\cdots,n, each holding a set of observed samples, 𝒮1,⋯,𝒮nsubscript𝒮1⋯subscript𝒮𝑛\mathcal{S}_{1},\cdots,\mathcal{S}_{n}. The server aims to extract common knowledge in the form of a hyper-posterior distribution without directly accessing clients’ datasets (as enforced by FL). The server communicates the learned hyper-posterior to clients, including those who participated in federated training and some new ones. The clients proceed by repeatedly drawing a prior from the received hyper-posterior and using it to calculate the optimal posterior per (5), involving any potential additional samples, 𝒮~isubscript~𝒮𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i} in the inference procedure. The goal is to find the optimal hyper-posterior, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, such that the posterior obtained through the described pipeline has a low true risk (1) for all clients. An overview of the setup is depicted in Fig. 1.

In the sequel, we consider hyper-posteriors, 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, that satisfy the condition of having a finite ϵ∈ℝ+italic-ϵsubscriptℝ\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{+} such that sampling P𝑃P from 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} preserves ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP for all clients. This assumption enables us to use Corollary 3.1.1 and is rather weak as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon can be arbitrarily, albeit not infinitely, large. Analogous to the procedure in Section 3, we establish PAC bounds for the pair 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} and 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. We derive a closed-form formula for the optimal hyper-posterior, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, which minimizes the PAC bound, and verify that 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} satisfies the privacy assumption. Finally, we establish a PAC bound for new clients who sample their priors from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} without participating in the federated learning process. An interpretation through the principle of maximum entropy [Jaynes, 1957] and all proofs are provided in Appendices 8.1 and 8.2, respectively.

Server-level PAC-Bayesian bound.

Following the introduced inference setup, the quality of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} can be measured by server-level true risk, defined as:

ℒS​(𝒬,𝒟,𝒮,𝐦~)superscriptℒ𝑆𝒬𝒟𝒮~𝐦\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{S}(\mathcal{Q},\mathcal{D},\mathcal{S},\mathbf{\tilde{m}}) ≔1n​∑i=1n𝔼P∼𝒬𝔼𝒮~i∼𝒟im~i⁡ℒC​(ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i∪𝒮~i),𝒟i).≔absent1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript~𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖superscriptℒ𝐶superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript~𝒮𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}}}\mathcal{L}^{C}(\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}\cup\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i}). (7)

Equation (7) averages the true loss across all clients, accounting for every possible set of new samples, 𝒮~~𝒮\tilde{\mathcal{S}}, with sizes specified by 𝐦~~𝐦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. The data generating distributions 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} are unknown in the true loss definition per (7), calling for an empirical estimation merely based on the available information:

ℒ^S​(𝒬,𝒮)superscript^ℒ𝑆𝒬𝒮\displaystyle\hat{\mathcal{L}}^{S}(\mathcal{Q},\mathcal{S}) ≔1n​∑i=1n𝔼P∼𝒬ℒ^C​(ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i),𝒮i),≔absent1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬superscript^ℒ𝐶superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖\displaystyle\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\hat{\mathcal{L}}^{C}(\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}),\mathcal{S}_{i}), (8)

where observed samples replace potential future data. We refer to (8) as the server-level empirical loss because it can be computed by the server by collecting summands from clients.

Below, we present our first main contribution, which is a PAC bound on server-level risks.

Theorem 4.1.

Let ℓ​(⋅,⋅)∈[a,b]ℓ⋅⋅𝑎𝑏\ell(\cdot,\cdot)\in[a,b] be a bounded loss function, β≥1/n𝛽1𝑛\beta\geq 1/n,

Δi≔1nmin{b−a,b(e2​β​m~imi+m~i​(b−a)−e−2​β​m~imi+m~i​(b−a))},∀i∈{1,⋯,n}.\displaystyle\Delta_{i}\coloneqq\frac{1}{n}\min\big{\{}b-a,b\big{(}e^{\frac{2\beta\tilde{m}_{i}}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}(b-a)}-e^{\frac{-2\beta\tilde{m}_{i}}{m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}}(b-a)}\big{)}\big{\}}\quad,\quad\forall i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}.

Assume clients employ the optimal posterior with parameter β𝛽\beta. Let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} be a hyper-posterior such that sampling P𝑃P from 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} preserves ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP for all clients. For every hyper-prior 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} independent from 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}, υ>0𝜐0\upsilon>0, λ>n2+υ𝜆subscript𝑛2𝜐\lambda>n_{2}+\upsilon, and confidence level δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1),

ℒS​(𝒬,𝒟,𝒮,𝐦~)≤superscriptℒ𝑆𝒬𝒟𝒮~𝐦absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{S}(\mathcal{Q},\mathcal{D},\mathcal{S},\mathbf{\tilde{m}})\leq −1n​β​∑i=1n𝔼P∼𝒬ln⁡ZβC​(P,𝒮i)+(1n​β+n2+υλ)​K​L​(𝒬∥𝒫)1𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖1𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛2𝜐𝜆𝐾𝐿conditional𝒬𝒫\displaystyle\frac{-1}{n\beta}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})+\big{(}\frac{1}{n\beta}+\frac{n_{2}+\upsilon}{\lambda}\big{)}KL(\mathcal{Q}\|\mathcal{P})
+β​(b−a)28​n​∑i=1n1mi+λ​∑i=1nΔi28​(n2+υ)+1n​ln⁡(1δ),𝛽superscript𝑏𝑎28𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝑚𝑖𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖28subscript𝑛2𝜐1𝑛1𝛿\displaystyle+\frac{\beta(b-a)^{2}}{8n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m_{i}}+\frac{\lambda\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}^{2}}{8(n_{2}+\upsilon)}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\ln{(\frac{1}{\delta})}, (9)

holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over 𝒮i∼𝒟imisimilar-tosubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}} and 𝒮~i∼𝒟im~isimilar-tosubscript~𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{\tilde{m}_{i}} for i=1,⋯,n𝑖1⋯𝑛i=1,\cdots,n.

The constant υ𝜐\upsilon can be chosen very small and avoids numerical issues when n2=0subscript𝑛20n_{2}=0. The bound in (9) depends on the number of clients and the current dataset sizes, n𝑛n and 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m}. Additionally, it relies on a prediction of the number of clients who will have new samples and the corresponding number of new samples, n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} and 𝐦~~𝐦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. While the server knows n𝑛n and 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m}, the estimates for n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} and 𝐦~~𝐦\mathbf{\tilde{m}} might be coarse. The following lemma states that a pessimistic forecast results in a looser upper bound.

Lemma 4.2.

If the number of new samples of client i𝑖i, m~i≥0subscript~𝑚𝑖0\tilde{m}_{i}\geq 0, is unknown, Theorem 4.1 holds when replacing ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i} with (b−a)/n𝑏𝑎𝑛(b-a)/n and counting client i𝑖i in n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}, i.e., as if m~i>0subscript~𝑚𝑖0\tilde{m}_{i}>0.

The asymptotic behavior and non-vacuousness of the client-level and server-level bounds are discussed in Appendix 8.3.1.

Optimal hyper-posterior.

Our algorithm picks the optimal hyper-posterior, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, leading to the lowest upper bound on the server-level true risk per (4). Inspecting the structural similarity between the server and client-level bounds in (4) and (9), we arrive at a closed-form formula for 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}.

Corollary 4.2.1.

When clients use the optimal posterior, Qi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑄𝑖Q^{*}_{i}, the optimal hyper-posterior is a Gibbs distribution with parameter τ=λ/(λ+β​n​(n2+υ))𝜏𝜆𝜆𝛽𝑛subscript𝑛2𝜐\tau=\lambda/\big{(}\lambda+\beta n(n_{2}+\upsilon)\big{)}:

𝒬∗​(P)=𝒫​(P)⋅exp⁡(τ​∑i=1nln⁡(ZβC​(P,𝒮i)))/ZτS​(𝒫,𝒮),superscript𝒬𝑃⋅𝒫𝑃𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑆𝜏𝒫𝒮\displaystyle\mathcal{Q}^{*}(P)=\mathcal{P}(P)\cdot\exp\Bigl{(}\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ln\big{(}Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\big{)}\Bigr{)}/Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S}),

where ZτS​(𝒫,𝒮)≔𝔼P∼𝒫exp⁡(τ​∑i=1nln⁡(ZβC​(P,𝒮i)))≔subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑆𝜏𝒫𝒮subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒫𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S})\coloneqq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\exp\big{(}\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ln\big{(}Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\big{)}\big{)} is a normalization constant.

The parameter τ𝜏\tau depends on the number of clients from different types, n𝑛n and n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}, but not on the number of samples, 𝐦𝐦\mathbf{m} and 𝐦~~𝐦\mathbf{\tilde{m}}. If n2subscript𝑛2n_{2} is unknown, it can be replaced by counting i𝑖i in n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}, consistently with Lemma 4.2. In this case, a looser upper bound would be minimized.

The privacy of sampling a prior from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is crucial to obtain ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} for plugging it into the client-level bound (6) and for employing Theorem 4.1. We rely on a result by Mir [2012] that proves the DP of sampling from the Gibbs distribution.

Lemma 4.3.

A prior sampled from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} preserves ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i}-DP for client i𝑖i, where ϵi=2​β​τ​(b−a)/misubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2𝛽𝜏𝑏𝑎subscript𝑚𝑖\epsilon_{i}=2\beta\tau(b-a)/m_{i} .

As a result, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} satisfies the privacy assumption of Theorem 4.1 with ϵ=maxi∈{1,⋯,n}⁡ϵiitalic-ϵsubscript𝑖1⋯𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon=\max_{i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}}\epsilon_{i}. Complementary discussions regarding the role of DP in our framework are available in Appendix 8.4.

PAC-Bayesian bound for new clients.

So far, we considered a fixed set of existing clients who participate in training the optimal hyper-posterior. In a realistic FL setup, there might be new clients (see c444) who join the system later and hence, do not engage in federated training. A new client holds a presumably small set of samples which leads to overfitting. Assuming the existing and new clients are similar, it is constructive for the new clients to readily employ 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} without having contributed to training it. In this section, we establish a PAC bound for such new clients.

In Section 3, we introduced the distribution 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} to represent the similarity among the existing clients. Consistently, we expect that a new client ι𝜄\iota is sampled from the same distribution, (𝒟ι,m~ι)∼𝒯similar-tosubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄𝒯(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T}. In line with the previous notation, m~ιsubscript~𝑚𝜄\tilde{m}_{\iota} is the cardinality of the set 𝒮~ι∼𝒟ιm~ιsimilar-tosubscript~𝒮𝜄superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}} employed by client ι𝜄\iota for personalization but held out from FL. We present below our second PAC-Bayesian bound.

Lemma 4.4.

For a new client ι𝜄\iota sampled from 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} adopting ℚ∗superscriptℚ\mathds{Q}^{*} and 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} as per Corollaries 3.1.1, 4.2.1,

𝔼(𝒟ι,m~ι)∼𝒯𝔼𝒮~ι∼𝒟ιm~ι𝔼P∼𝒬∗⁡ℒC​(ℚ∗​(P,𝒮~ι),𝒟ι)≤subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄𝒯subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript~𝒮𝜄superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃superscript𝒬superscriptℒ𝐶superscriptℚ𝑃subscript~𝒮𝜄subscript𝒟𝜄absent\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}}}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}^{*}}\mathcal{L}^{C}\big{(}\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}),\mathcal{D}_{\iota}\big{)}\leq −(1n​β+n2+υλ)​ln⁡ZτS​(𝒫,𝒮)1𝑛𝛽subscript𝑛2𝜐𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑆𝜏𝒫𝒮\displaystyle-(\frac{1}{n\beta}+\frac{n_{2}+\upsilon}{\lambda})\ln Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S})
+(b−a)28​n​(β​∑i=1n1mi+λn2+υ)+1n​ln⁡(1δ),superscript𝑏𝑎28𝑛𝛽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛1subscript𝑚𝑖𝜆subscript𝑛2𝜐1𝑛1𝛿\displaystyle+\frac{(b-a)^{2}}{8n}\big{(}\beta\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m_{i}}+\frac{\lambda}{n_{2}+\upsilon}\big{)}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}\ln(\frac{1}{\delta}),

holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over (𝒟ι,m~ι)∼𝒯similar-tosubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄𝒯(\mathcal{D}_{\iota},\tilde{m}_{\iota})\sim\mathcal{T} and 𝒮~ι∼𝒟ιm~ιsimilar-tosubscript~𝒮𝜄superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜄subscript~𝑚𝜄\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{\iota}\sim\mathcal{D}_{\iota}^{\tilde{m}_{\iota}}.

Since 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is tailored to minimize the server-level bound for existing clients, the bound in Lemma 4.4 is looser than that of Theorem 4.1 with 𝒬=𝒬∗𝒬superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}=\mathcal{Q}^{*} (see Appendix 8.2.5 for the proof). This motivates the clients to actively engage in training 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} rather than readily employing the learned hyper-posterior.

5 Practical federated implementation

In Section 3, we motivated learning a distribution over priors when dealing with heterogeneous clients, where selecting a single best prior may not be accurate or feasible. Consequently, we derived the optimal hyper-posterior in Corollary 4.2.1. In this section, we address the computational limitations at both the client and server levels and propose a practical PFL algorithm.

Models at the client level.

The formula for 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} in Corollary 4.2.1 relies on ZβC​(P,𝒮i)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝛽𝐶𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) for i∈{0,⋯,n}𝑖0⋯𝑛i\in\{0,\cdots,n\}. As per Corollary 3.1.1, calculating ZβC​(P,𝒮i)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝛽𝐶𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) entails computing the expectation over all hypotheses sampled from the prior, which is in general intractable. We consider the negative log-likelihood loss and set β=mi+m~i𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, which results in Zβsubscript𝑍𝛽Z_{\beta} aligning with the LML, as discussed in Section 3. We calculate the LML in two scenarios: when clients use Gaussian Processes (GPs) or Bayesian Neural Networks (BNNs). MLL is readily available in closed-form for GPs but is intractable for BNNs. To address this, we adopt the approximation method described in Rothfuss et al. [2021].

Inspired by Fortuin et al. [2020], Rothfuss et al. [2021], we parameterize the GP mean and kernel by two deep neural networks (NN) and consider a Gaussian likelihood. The resulting model enhances the expressive power and scalability to high-dimensional data of GPs [Wilson et al., 2016]. Additional details about the models and likelihood formulas can be found in Appendices 8.3.2 and 8.3.3.

SVGD at the server level.

Given ZβC​(P,𝒮i)superscriptsubscript𝑍𝛽𝐶𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖Z_{\beta}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}), 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} is computable up to the constant ZτS​(𝒫,𝒮)subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝑆𝜏𝒫𝒮Z^{S}_{\tau}(\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S}), which leaves sampling from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} intractable. Following Rothfuss et al. [2021], we use Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [Liu and Wang, 2016] that approximates 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} as a set of priors, Pϕ1,⋯,Pϕksubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ1⋯subscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑘P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}}. Each prior Pϕκsubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} is parameterized by ϕκsubscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}. SVGD is initialized with a set of priors and then iteratively transports them to match 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}. This is achieved through a form of functional gradient descent on the SVGD loss (see Appendix 8.3.4), making it suitable for being integrated into an FL scheme. As SVGD is deterministic [Liu, 2017], the inherent privacy of 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} established in Lemma 4.3 is compromised. To reintroduce privacy, a conventional approach involves injecting noise into the SVGD gradients [Geyer et al., 2017]. We propose a privacy-preserving variant of PAC-PFL in Appendix 8.4.

Federated algorithm.

PAC-PFL leverages the FedAvg [McMahan et al., 2016] technique to minimize the SVGD loss. Initially, we sample Pϕ1,⋯,Pϕksubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ1⋯subscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑘P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}} from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}, which we define as a multi-variate Gaussian distribution with a diagonal covariance matrix. At each iteration, the server randomly selects a subset of existing clients to send ϕ1,⋯,ϕksubscriptbold-italic-ϕ1⋯subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑘\bm{\phi}_{1},\cdots,\bm{\phi}_{k}. The selected clients compute the SVGD gradients and send them back to the server. The server aggregates all gradients before using them to update the priors. A pseudocode is presented in Algorithm 1 with sub-routines Client_Update and SVGD_Update defined in Appendix 8.3.5. For a comprehensive list of parameters used in our theoretical results and algorithm, along with selection guidelines, please refer to Appendix 8.3.6.

6 Experiments

We evaluate PAC-PFL on four datasets: photovoltaic (PV) panels and polynomial datasets for regression, alongside FEMNIST [Caldas et al., 2019] and EMNIST [Cohen et al., 2017] datasets for classification. Our algorithm consistently outperforms federated and data-centric baselines, improving the prediction accuracy and the calibration of uncertainty estimates simultaneously. These enhancements are evident in reducing the variance and mean of these metrics across existing and new clients.

Datasets.

The PV dataset contains the PV generation time-series of multiple houses in a city. Each house is a client, and the clients are heterogeneous due to variations in location, shadows, and orientation relative to the sun. We consider 242424 existing and 242424 new clients. This section uses a highly heterogeneous scenario, called PV-EW, with a bimodal distribution over the clients: half oriented eastward and half westward. We use the PV-EW dataset once with 150150150 and once with 610610610 training samples per client. This dataset induces challenges (c111-c444).

The FEMNIST dataset consists of handwritten characters from various writers, treated as clients, and we employ it for 101010-way digit classification. Heterogeneity arises from distinct handwriting (c222). We select 404040 clients and examine two scenarios: one with 202020 and another with an average of 500500500 samples per client. In the low-data case (c333), we demonstrate PAC-PFL’s superior performance over all baselines. In the full-data case, we highlight the scalability of our algorithm with large datasets. The Polynomial and EMNIST datasets and other setups for using the PV dataset are detailed in Appendix 8.5. A summary of the employed datasets is provided in Table 1.

Baselines.

We compare PAC-PFL against two probabilistic PFL methods, pFedGP [Achituve et al., 2021] and pFedBayes [Zhang et al., 2022], and two frequentist PFL methods, MAML [Fallah et al., 2020] and MTL [Evgeniou and Pontil, 2004]. Additionally, we consider two non-federated approaches: Vanilla, where each client trains a model individually, and Pooled, where a single model is trained in a data-centric manner on a pooled dataset comprising all clients’ data. The Pooled approach is expected to perform poorly for heterogeneous clients due to the lack of personalization. Hyper-parameters for each method are tuned using cross-validation. Further baseline details can be found in Appendix 8.6.

Metrics.

We assess prediction accuracy and calibration for each client. For regression, we use root standardized mean squared error (RSMSE) that normalizes RMSE by the standard deviation of targets. For classification, we measure the percentage of correctly classified samples. Additionally, we compute the calibration error (CE), which quantifies the deviation of predicted confidence intervals from actual proportions of test data within those intervals [Kuleshov et al., 2018], using the formula in Rothfuss et al. [2021] (see 8.6.1). CE applies exclusively to probabilistic models and is irrelevant to frequentist baselines, such as MAML and MTL. In evaluating FL methods, the sample mean of a metric is often a biased estimate due to correlations across clients. We utilize box plots to analyze the distribution of metric values across clients, offering a more comprehensive understanding.

Results

The results for PV-EW (150) are presented in Fig. 2, highlighting several key findings. MAML does not perform well, likely because a single gradient descent step lacks the necessary personalization (c222), while MTL and pFedGP showcase their capability to capture heterogeneity. The limited sample size (c333) adversely impacts the performance of the local Vanilla GP. Notably, our method outperforms all baselines due to its strong personalization capability, addressing (c222), and inherent regularization, resolving (c333).

Test accuracy percentage on the FEMNIST dataset with 202020 samples per client and the EMNIST dataset for existing clients is provided in Table 2. Remarkably, PAC-PFL outperforms other baselines on both datasets. Complementary experimental results are reported in Appendix 8.6.

7 Conclusion

This paper presents PAC-PFL, a novel PFL algorithm that enables the learning of probabilistic models. The proposed approach learns a shared hyper-posterior in a federated manner, which clients use to sample their priors for personalized posterior inference. To prevent overfitting, PAC-PFL minimizes an upper bound on the true risk of the clients participating in federated training. Moreover, the learned hyper-posterior can be applied to new clients who did not participate in the training, resulting in positive transfer. Conducting experiments on a heterogeneous dataset of PV panels and on the FEMNIST dataset, we empirically demonstrate that PAC-PFL produces accurate and well-calibrated predictions.

There are two main directions for future research: improving client-level computational complexity (detailed in Appendix 8.3.7) and addressing the privacy-utility trade-off more effectively. Our framework leverages DP to derive valid generalization bounds despite having data-dependent priors and to avoid data leakage, as typical in FL. While our theoretical results in Section 4 show that our ideal pipeline provides DP, we forfeit this property due to the SVGD approximation technique. We empirically validated that PAC-PFL avoids overfitting, though the bounds might not hold. DP can be reintroduced to prevent data leakage using the common method of injecting noise during training [Geyer et al., 2017], as demonstrated in Appendix 8.4, but this may compromise accuracy [Bagdasaryan et al., 2019]. Exploring alternative privacy techniques is an avenue for future research.

Reproducibility statement

For all theorems and theoretical results, we present detailed assumptions and proofs in Appendix 8.2. Moreover, we provide a comprehensive table containing all parameters utilized throughout the paper in Appendix 8.3.6. This table highlights the interconnections between these parameters and marks the free parameters that can be tuned for optimal utilization of our algorithm.

Regarding the datasets, we employ the FEMNIST dataset, which is curated and maintained by the LEAF project [Caldas et al., 2019]. We utilize the original train-test split provided with the data, without any additional preprocessing. The PV dataset can be accessed via the following link: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/153MeAlntN4VORHdgYQ3wG3OylW0SlBf9?usp=sharing.

The source code for our PAC-PFL implementation using GP is accessible within the same Google Drive repository. Upon acceptance, we intend to make the source code for BNN publicly available. To facilitate the use of our software, we have incorporated a demonstration Jupyter Notebook in the source code repository. Furthermore, we have included pre-trained models for PAC-PFL and other baseline models for the PV dataset. Finally, we provide a notebook that generates the figures featured in the paper.

8 Appendix

8.1 Interpretation through the principle of maximum entropy

In this section, we provide additional justification for the optimal hyper-posterior derived in Corollary 4.2.1 based on the principle of maximum entropy [Jaynes, 1957]. The principle of maximum entropy suggests that when only the class of a distribution is known, the distribution with the highest entropy should be chosen as the least-informative default. The distribution class can be specified by certain moment constraints.This principle is motivated by two key reasons: first, maximizing entropy minimizes the amount of prior information embedded in the distribution, allowing for a more agnostic representation; second, it aligns with the observation that many physical systems tend to evolve towards configurations of maximal entropy over time. While the principle of maximum entropy is commonly employed to derive prior probability distributions in Bayesian inference [Merwe and Skilling, 2010], we utilize it in the context of obtaining the optimal hyper-posterior distribution.

Consider the following constrained maximum entropy problem:

max𝒬⁡H𝒫​(𝒬)subscript𝒬subscript𝐻𝒫𝒬\displaystyle\max_{\mathcal{Q}}\;H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q}) (10a)
s.t.−𝔼P∼𝒬ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)+I​(ϵi,mi,δ)≤−𝔼P∼𝒫ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)∀i∈{1,⋯,n}.formulae-sequences.t.subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖𝐼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝛿subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒫subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖for-all𝑖1⋯𝑛\displaystyle\textit{s.t.}\;-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})+I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)\leq-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\quad\forall i\in\{1,\cdots,n\}. (10b)

In Equation (10a), H𝒫​(𝒬)=−K​L​(𝒬∥𝒫)subscript𝐻𝒫𝒬𝐾𝐿conditional𝒬𝒫H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q})=-KL(\mathcal{Q}\|\mathcal{P}) represents Jaynes’ entropy with the hyper-prior 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} serving as the invariant measure [Jaynes, 1957]. The objective is to maximize this entropy subject to n𝑛n constraints on the expectations of ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) under the distribution 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, as given in (10b). The constants ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖\epsilon_{i} and I​(ϵi,mi,δ)𝐼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝛿I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta) are determined by Lemma 4.3 and Theorem 3.1, respectively. Below, we establish a connection between the maximum entropy problem and our approach in Section 4.

Proposition 1.

The minimizer of the server-level upper bound, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, derived in Corollary 4.2.1, coincides with the maximizer of the constrained maximum entropy problem presented in (10a)-(10b), when the maximum entropy problem is solved by optimizing the Lagrange function:

arg⁡max𝒬⁡H𝒫​(𝒬)+τ​∑i=1n(𝔼P∼𝒬ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)−I​(ϵi,mi,δ)−𝔼P∼𝒫ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)),subscript𝒬subscript𝐻𝒫𝒬𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖𝐼subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝛿subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒫subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\displaystyle\arg\max_{\mathcal{Q}}\;H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q})+\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Bigl{(}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})-I(\epsilon_{i},m_{i},\delta)-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{P}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})\Bigr{)}, (11)

where the Lagrange multiplier τ𝜏\tau is used for all constraints. The constant τ𝜏\tau is as per Corollary 4.2.1.

Proof.

Let 𝒬~∗superscript~𝒬\tilde{\mathcal{Q}}^{*} denote the maximizer of the Lagrange function in (11). By removing the terms in (11) that are constant with respect to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, we obtain:

𝒬~∗=arg⁡max𝒬⁡H𝒫​(𝒬)+τ​∑i=1n𝔼P∼𝒬ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i).superscript~𝒬subscript𝒬subscript𝐻𝒫𝒬𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{Q}}^{*}=\arg\max_{\mathcal{Q}}\;H_{\mathcal{P}}(\mathcal{Q})+\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}). (12)

According to the definition of Jaynes’ entropy,

𝒬~∗=arg⁡min𝒬⁡1τ​K​L​(𝒬∥𝒫)−∑i=1n𝔼P∼𝒬ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i),superscript~𝒬subscript𝒬1𝜏𝐾𝐿conditional𝒬𝒫superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃𝒬subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\displaystyle\tilde{\mathcal{Q}}^{*}=\arg\min_{\mathcal{Q}}\;\frac{1}{\tau}KL(\mathcal{Q}\|\mathcal{P})-\sum_{i=1}^{n}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}}\ln Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}), (13)

where we have multiplied the objective in (12) by −1/τ1𝜏-1/\tau and changed maximization into minimization. By substituting the formula for τ𝜏\tau, one can verify that (13) is equivalent to the server-level upper bound, except for some constant values. Hence, 𝒬~∗=𝒬∗superscript~𝒬superscript𝒬\tilde{\mathcal{Q}}^{*}=\mathcal{Q}^{*}. ∎

The maximum entropy interpretation of 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} allows us to analyze the effect of sampling P𝑃P from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} on client-level bounds. If client i𝑖i chooses not to participate in FL and decides not to use 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, the best alternative approach is to sample P𝑃P from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}. The following corollary provides a comparison between sampling P𝑃P from 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} and sampling P𝑃P from 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}.

Corollary 8.0.1.

The i𝑖i-th constraint in (10b) imposes that the expected upper bound for client i𝑖i is tighter when sampling the prior P𝑃P from the optimal hyper-posterior, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}, compared to sampling from the hyper-prior, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P}.

Proof.

Since a prior which is sampled from the hyper-prior is no longer data-dependent, we utilize the result from Alquier et al. [2016] to derive a bound for client i𝑖i:

ℒC​(Qi,𝒟i)≤ℒ^C​(Qi,𝒮i)+1β​(K​L​(Qi∥P)+β2​(b−a)28​mi+ln⁡(1δ)),superscriptℒ𝐶subscript𝑄𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖superscript^ℒ𝐶subscript𝑄𝑖subscript𝒮𝑖1𝛽𝐾𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑄𝑖𝑃superscript𝛽2superscript𝑏𝑎28subscript𝑚𝑖1𝛿\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{C}(Q_{i},\mathcal{D}_{i})\leq\mathcal{\hat{L}}^{C}(Q_{i},\mathcal{S}_{i})+\frac{1}{\beta}\Big{(}KL(Q_{i}\|P)+\frac{\beta^{2}(b-a)^{2}}{8m_{i}}+\ln{(\frac{1}{\delta})}\Big{)}, (14)

which holds with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over 𝒮i∼𝒟imisimilar-tosubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}}. The upper bound in (14) is equal to the upper bound in (4) with 𝒮~i=∅subscript~𝒮𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}=\emptyset, except for the constant term I𝐼I. Therefore, the posterior that minimizes the right-hand side of (14) is the same as ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i)superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) derived in Corollary 3.1.1 with 𝒮~i=∅subscript~𝒮𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}=\emptyset. By plugging ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i)superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) into (14), we obtain the counterpart of (6):

ℒC​(ℚ∗​(P,𝒮i),𝒟i)≤superscriptℒ𝐶superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖absent\displaystyle\mathcal{L}^{C}(\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}),\mathcal{D}_{i})\leq 1β​(−ln⁡Zβ​(P,𝒮i)+β2​(b−a)28​mi+ln⁡(1δ)),1𝛽subscript𝑍𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖superscript𝛽2superscript𝑏𝑎28subscript𝑚𝑖1𝛿\displaystyle\frac{1}{\beta}\Big{(}-\ln{Z_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})}+\frac{\beta^{2}(b-a)^{2}}{8m_{i}}+\ln{(\frac{1}{\delta})}\Big{)}, (15)

holding with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta over 𝒮i∼𝒟imisimilar-tosubscript𝒮𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}\sim\mathcal{D}_{i}^{m_{i}}. The i𝑖i-th constraint in (10b) is obtained by taking the expectation of the upper bounds in (6) and (15) when P∼𝒬∗similar-to𝑃superscript𝒬P\sim\mathcal{Q}^{*} and P∼𝒫similar-to𝑃𝒫P\sim\mathcal{P}, respectively, and enforcing that the former is smaller than the latter. ∎

According to Corollary 8.0.1, participating in FL is beneficial for client i𝑖i if the i𝑖i-th constraint is satisfied. However, since we solved the constrained problem per (10a)-(10b) using the Lagrange method with a single multiplier, the constraints might be violated. The constraints are more likely to be satisfied when τ𝜏\tau is large, which can be achieved by having small n𝑛n, n2subscript𝑛2n_{2}, and β𝛽\beta, while simultaneously having a large value for λEsubscript𝜆𝐸\lambda_{E}. In other words, when there are fewer clients participating in FL, the hyper-posterior is more likely to provide improvements for those clients.

Remark.

In a similar manner, we can avoid any PAC arguments and use the principle of minimum cross entropy for calculating the posterior. With these two rules, the optimal posterior and hyper-posterior are the same as those obtained by minimizing client-level and server-level PAC bounds.

8.2 Proofs and derivations

We first mention without proof a powerful lemma, called the change of measure inequality, that is the basis of proving PAC bounds in most papers. The statement below is adapted from the Appendix of Pentina and Lampert [2014].

Lemma 8.1 ([Pentina and Lampert, 2014]).

Let f𝑓f be a random variable taking values in a set A𝐴A and let X1,⋯,Xlsubscript𝑋1⋯subscript𝑋𝑙X_{1},\cdots,X_{l} be l𝑙l independent random variables with each Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k} distributed according to μksubscript𝜇𝑘\mu_{k} over the set Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k}. Then, for any fixed distributions π,ρ𝜋𝜌\pi,\rho over A𝐴A and any γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0, we have that

𝔼f∼ρ[∑k=1l(ξk​(f)−gk​(f,Xk))]≤1γ​K​L​(ρ∥π)+1γ​ψ​(γ),subscript𝔼similar-to𝑓𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑙subscript𝜉𝑘𝑓subscript𝑔𝑘𝑓subscript𝑋𝑘1𝛾𝐾𝐿conditional𝜌𝜋1𝛾𝜓𝛾\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{f\sim\rho}\Big{[}\sum_{k=1}^{l}\bigl{(}\xi_{k}(f)-g_{k}(f,X_{k})\bigr{)}\Big{]}\leq\frac{1}{\gamma}KL(\rho\|\pi)+\frac{1}{\gamma}\psi(\gamma),

When ξk−gksubscript𝜉𝑘subscript𝑔𝑘\xi_{k}-g_{k} is bounded, we bound the expectation of the log moment-generating function in Corollary 8.2.1, which uses the Hoeffding’s lemma stated below.

Lemma 8.2 ([Hoeffding, 1963]).

Let Y𝑌Y be a zero-mean real-valued random variable such that Y∈[a,b]𝑌𝑎𝑏Y\in[a,b] almost surely, i.e. with probability one. Then for any γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0:

𝔼[eγ​Y]≤eγ28​(b−a)2.𝔼superscript𝑒𝛾𝑌superscript𝑒superscript𝛾28superscript𝑏𝑎2\displaystyle\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}\big{[}e^{\gamma Y}\big{]}\leq e^{\frac{\gamma^{2}}{8}(b-a)^{2}}.

Proof of Corollary 8.2.1.

By taking the expectation of the moment-generating function w.r.t every Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k},

∎

One can utilize Markov’s inequality111According to Markov’s inequality, if X𝑋X is a nonnegative random variable and a>0𝑎0a>0, then Pr⁡[X≥a]≤𝔼[X]/aPr𝑋𝑎𝔼𝑋𝑎\Pr[X\geq a]\leq\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]/a. to remove the expectation in Corollary 8.2.1 and obtain a probabilistic bound on ψ​(γ)𝜓𝛾\psi(\gamma). We will use Corollary 8.2.1 multiple times, and thus, postpone applying Markov’s inequality to avoid simultaneous stochastic inequalities which must be combined with a union bound argument.

8.2.1 Proof of Theorem 4.1

The proof of Theorem 4.1 is carried out in three steps. The first two steps bound the true risk of clients with 𝒮~i=∅subscript~𝒮𝑖\tilde{\mathcal{S}}_{i}=\varnothing and clients with enlarged datasets, respectively. By merging these two, we will obtain a bound on the server-level true risk. In the last step, the closed-form formula of the optimal posterior is exploited to make some simplifications. The main assumptions are independence of clients (guaranteeing independence of Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k} in Lemma 8.1), boundedness of the loss function (needed to apply Corollary 8.2.1), adoption of the optimal posterior (yielding the bound per (6)), and existence of a finite ϵ∈ℝ+italic-ϵsubscriptℝ\epsilon\in\mathbb{R}_{+} such that sampling P𝑃P from 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} preserves ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP for all clients (required to use Corollary 3.1.1).

Step 𝟏1\mathbf{1}.

We apply Lemma 8.1 with the following instances: take l=∑i=1nmi𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑚𝑖l=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}m_{i} and assign a random variable to each observed sample by clients, Xk=𝐳i​jsubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐳𝑖𝑗X_{k}=\mathbf{z}_{ij}, where 𝐳i​jsubscript𝐳𝑖𝑗\mathbf{z}_{ij} is the j𝑗j’th sample of 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}. Let α:{1,⋯,l}→{1,⋯,n}:𝛼absent→1⋯𝑙1⋯𝑛\alpha:\{1,\cdots,l\}\xrightarrow{}\{1,\cdots,n\} be a mapping from each random variable Xksubscript𝑋𝑘X_{k} to the corresponding client, α​(k)=i𝛼𝑘𝑖\alpha(k)=i if Xk=𝐳i​jsubscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝐳𝑖𝑗X_{k}=\mathbf{z}_{ij} for some j𝑗j. Correspondingly, we take μk=𝒟α​(k)subscript𝜇𝑘subscript𝒟𝛼𝑘\mu_{k}=\mathcal{D}_{\alpha(k)} to be the respective distribution. Further, we set f=(P,h1,⋯,hn)𝑓𝑃subscriptℎ1⋯subscriptℎ𝑛f=(P,h_{1},\cdots,h_{n}) to be a tuple of one prior and n𝑛n hypotheses and consider distributions π=(𝒫,P,⋯,P)𝜋𝒫𝑃⋯𝑃\pi=(\mathcal{P},P,\cdots,P) and ρ=(𝒬,ℚ∗​(P,𝒮1),⋯,ℚ∗​(P,𝒮n))𝜌𝒬superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮1⋯superscriptℚ𝑃subscript𝒮𝑛\rho=\bigl{(}\mathcal{Q},\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{1}),\cdots,\mathds{Q}^{*}(P,\mathcal{S}_{n})\bigr{)} over it. By applying Corollary 8.2.1, one obtains:

which holds since ∑i∈AΔi2≤ρ​(A)​((b−a)/n)2subscript𝑖𝐴superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖2𝜌𝐴superscript𝑏𝑎𝑛2\sum_{i\in A}\Delta_{i}^{2}\leq\rho(A)\bigl{(}(b-a)/n\bigr{)}^{2} and υ≥0𝜐0\upsilon\geq 0.

8.2.3 Proof of Corollary 4.2.1

The optimal hyper-posterior minimizes the upper bound on the true server-level risk established in 9. By utilizing the structural similarity between the server-level and client-level upper-bounds, equations (9) and (4), we employ Corollary 3.1.1 to obtain 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}.

8.2.5 Looser upper bound for new clients

We consider Theorem 4.1 when 𝒬=𝒬∗𝒬superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}=\mathcal{Q}^{*} and simplify the terms in the upper bound that involve 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}:

=1n​β​τ​𝔼P∼𝒬∗(−τ​∑i=1nln⁡ZβC​(P,𝒮i)+ln⁡𝒬∗​(P)𝒫​(P))absent1𝑛𝛽𝜏subscript𝔼similar-to𝑃superscript𝒬𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑍𝐶𝛽𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖superscript𝒬𝑃𝒫𝑃\displaystyle=\frac{1}{n\beta\tau}\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}_{P\sim\mathcal{Q}^{*}}\big{(}-\tau\sum_{i=1}^{n}\ln Z^{C}_{\beta}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})+\ln\frac{\mathcal{Q}^{*}(P)}{\mathcal{P}(P)}\Big{)} (31)

Equation (31) follows from the KL divergence definition and (32) is obtained by substituting the closed-form formula of 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*} derived in Corollary 4.2.1 into the expression. To compare the bound in Theorem 4.1 with Lemma 4.4, we can substitute the first two terms in Theorem 4.1 with (32). In order for the bound in Lemma 4.4 to be looser than this substituted bound, it is sufficient to show that ∑i=1nΔi2≤(b−a)2/nsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖2superscript𝑏𝑎2𝑛\sum_{i=1}^{n}\Delta_{i}^{2}\leq(b-a)^{2}/n, which is true based on the definition of ΔisubscriptΔ𝑖\Delta_{i} in Theorem 4.1.

8.3 Details of the algorithm

8.3.1 Asymptotic behavior and non-vacuousness of bounds

We analyze the asymptotic behavior of the client-level and server-level bounds as the number of samples per client and the number of existing clients approach infinity, i.e., mi→∞absent→subscript𝑚𝑖m_{i}\xrightarrow{}{}\infty and n→∞absent→𝑛n\xrightarrow{}{}\infty. A PAC bound is considered consistent when the gap between the true and empirical risks goes to zero. The client-level and server-level bounds are consistent if and only if: a) β∈Ω​(1)𝛽Ω1\beta\in\Omega(1), b) β∈o​(mi)𝛽𝑜subscript𝑚𝑖\beta\in o(m_{i}), c) λ∈Ω​(n2)𝜆Ωsubscript𝑛2\lambda\in\Omega(n_{2}), d) λ∈o​(n​(n2+υ))𝜆𝑜𝑛subscript𝑛2𝜐\lambda\in o(n(n_{2}+\upsilon)). Here, o𝑜o and ΩΩ\Omega represent the small-oh and big-omega notations for function growth rate [Cormen et al., 2022].

Non-vacuous bounds are essential, ensuring that the terms independent of the posterior or the hyper-posterior are not excessively large such that the bound on the true loss holds regardless of the empirical loss. To achieve a non-vacuous bound, it is necessary (but not sufficient) that b−a<8𝑏𝑎8b-a<8 and that ϵi<2​(b−a)subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖2𝑏𝑎\epsilon_{i}<\sqrt{2(b-a)}. The latter condition can be converted into an upper bound on λ𝜆\lambda based on the results from Lemma 4.3.

In our experiments, we follow Rothfuss et al. [2021] and set β=mi+m~i𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖subscript~𝑚𝑖\beta=m_{i}+\tilde{m}_{i}, leading to a non-vanishing gap between the true and empirical risks at the client and server levels. However, this choice simplifies the computations as discussed in Section 5. Moreover, this choice leads to faster decay of the KL term in both the client-level and server-level bounds, which can be advantageous when misubscript𝑚𝑖m_{i} is small [Rothfuss et al., 2021]. We tune λ𝜆\lambda, while respecting the non-vacuousness condition, to manipulate the regularization strength of the hyper-posterior towards the hyper-prior.

8.3.2 Background on GP

Below, we provide additional details regarding the GP models we use. For a more comprehensive overview on GPs, please refer to Rasmussen and Williams [2005]. In the rest of this section, we express the dataset of client i𝑖i as 𝒮i=(𝐗i,𝐲i)subscript𝒮𝑖subscript𝐗𝑖subscript𝐲𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i}=(\mathbf{X}_{i},\mathbf{y}_{i}), where 𝐗i∈R𝐱mi⊂ℝmi×dsubscript𝐗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑅𝐱subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖𝑑\mathbf{X}_{i}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}^{m_{i}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}\times d} is a matrix with row j𝑗j representing the features of the j𝑗j-th sample in 𝒮isubscript𝒮𝑖\mathcal{S}_{i} denoted as 𝐱i​j∈R𝐱subscript𝐱𝑖𝑗subscript𝑅𝐱\mathbf{x}_{ij}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}. The corresponding target values are stored in the vector 𝐲i∈Rymi⊂ℝmisubscript𝐲𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑦subscript𝑚𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖\mathbf{y}_{i}\in R_{y}^{m_{i}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}}, with row j𝑗j representing the target value yi​j∈Rysubscript𝑦𝑖𝑗subscript𝑅𝑦y_{ij}\in R_{y}.

GP with a deep mean and a deep kernel [Wilson et al., 2016].

Let Pϕ​(h)=𝒢​𝒫​(h|mϕ​(𝐱),kϕ​(𝐱,𝐱′))subscript𝑃bold-italic-ϕℎ𝒢𝒫conditionalℎsubscript𝑚bold-italic-ϕ𝐱subscript𝑘bold-italic-ϕ𝐱superscript𝐱′P_{\bm{\phi}}(h)=\mathcal{GP}(h|m_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x}),k_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x^{\prime}})) denote a GP prior specified by a deep mean function, mϕsubscript𝑚bold-italic-ϕm_{\bm{\phi}}, a deep kernel function, kϕsubscript𝑘bold-italic-ϕk_{\bm{\phi}}, and a Gaussian likelihood with noise standard deviation, σϕ∈ℝ+subscript𝜎bold-italic-ϕsubscriptℝ\sigma_{\bm{\phi}}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}. The vector ϕ∈ℝdϕbold-italic-ϕsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑑italic-ϕ\bm{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\phi}} concatenates all learnable hyper-parameters of the GP prior, including the mean parameters, kernel parameters, and the likelihood noise. The mean function, mϕ:R𝐱→ℝ:subscript𝑚bold-italic-ϕabsent→subscript𝑅𝐱ℝm_{\bm{\phi}}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow[]{}\mathbb{R}, is implemented as a multi-layer NN with weights given by ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\bm{\phi}}, hyperbolic tangent activation functions in the hidden layers, and linear output functions in the output layer. The kernel function is a squared-exponential (SE) kernel applied on top of an NN, defined as:

kϕ​(𝐱,𝐱′)≔e​x​p​(−12​‖fϕ​(𝐱)−fϕ​(𝐱′)‖22)∈[0,1].≔subscript𝑘bold-italic-ϕ𝐱superscript𝐱′𝑒𝑥𝑝12superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑓bold-italic-ϕ𝐱subscript𝑓bold-italic-ϕsuperscript𝐱′2201\displaystyle k_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x},\mathbf{x^{\prime}})\coloneqq exp(\frac{-1}{2}\|f_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x})-f_{\bm{\phi}}(\mathbf{x^{\prime}})\|_{2}^{2})\in[0,1].

The function fϕ:R𝐱→ℝdf:subscript𝑓bold-italic-ϕabsent→subscript𝑅𝐱superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑓f_{\bm{\phi}}:R_{\mathbf{x}}\xrightarrow[]{}\mathbb{R}^{d_{f}} represents an NN with weights given by ϕbold-italic-ϕ{\bm{\phi}} that maps the typically high-dimensional feature vector, 𝐱∈R𝐱⊂ℝd𝐱subscript𝑅𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in R_{\mathbf{x}}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}, to a lower-dimensional output vector in ℝdfsuperscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑓\mathbb{R}^{d_{f}}, where in our specific case, dfsubscript𝑑𝑓d_{f} is two. Deep kernels serve as feature extractors and allow for learning more sophisticated representations from the data [Ober et al., 2021]. The length scale of the SE kernel is set to 111 because the weights of the output layer of fϕsubscript𝑓bold-italic-ϕf_{\bm{\phi}} can be freely chosen to compensate for it.

Computing the LML.

As mentioned in Section 5, when employing a GP prior, negative log likelihood loss, and setting β=mi𝛽subscript𝑚𝑖\beta=m_{i}, the quantity ln⁡ZmiC​(P,𝒮i)superscriptsubscript𝑍subscript𝑚𝑖𝐶𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖\ln Z_{m_{i}}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i}) defined in Corollary 3.1.1 corresponds to the LML of the GP. For client i𝑖i using the prior Pϕκsubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅P_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}, the closed-form formula for the LML is as follows:

ln⁡ZmiC​(P,𝒮i)=ln⁡Pr⁡[𝐲i|𝐗i]=superscriptsubscript𝑍subscript𝑚𝑖𝐶𝑃subscript𝒮𝑖Prconditionalsubscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐗𝑖absent\displaystyle\ln Z_{m_{i}}^{C}(P,\mathcal{S}_{i})=\ln\Pr[\mathbf{y}_{i}|\mathbf{X}_{i}]= −12​(𝐲i−𝐦κ,i)⊤​(𝐊κ,i+σϕκ2​𝐈)−1​(𝐲i−𝐦κ,i)12superscriptsubscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐦𝜅𝑖topsuperscriptsubscript𝐊𝜅𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅2𝐈1subscript𝐲𝑖subscript𝐦𝜅𝑖\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf{y}_{i}-\mathbf{m}_{\kappa,i})^{\top}(\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i}+\sigma_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}^{2}\mathbf{I})^{-1}(\mathbf{y}_{i}-\mathbf{m}_{\kappa,i})
−12​ln⁡|𝐊κ,i+σϕκ2​𝐈|−mi2​ln⁡(2​π),12subscript𝐊𝜅𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅2𝐈subscript𝑚𝑖22𝜋\displaystyle-\frac{1}{2}\ln|\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i}+\sigma_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}^{2}\mathbf{I}|-\frac{m_{i}}{2}\ln(2\pi), (33)

where 𝐦κ,i∈ℝmisubscript𝐦𝜅𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖\mathbf{m}_{\kappa,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} is given by [mϕκ​(𝐱i​1),⋯,mϕκ​(𝐱i​mi)]Tsuperscriptsubscript𝑚subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅subscript𝐱𝑖1⋯subscript𝑚subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖𝑇[m_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}(\mathbf{x}_{i1}),\cdots,m_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}}(\mathbf{x}_{im_{i}})]^{T} and |𝐀|𝐀|\mathbf{A}| denotes the determinant of the matrix 𝐀𝐀\mathbf{A}. The matrix 𝐊κ,i∈ℝmi×misubscript𝐊𝜅𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖subscript𝑚𝑖\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}\times m_{i}} is the kernel matrix associated with the kernel function kϕκsubscript𝑘subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅k_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} applied to the feature matrix 𝐗isubscript𝐗𝑖\mathbf{X}_{i}. Furthermore, 𝐊κ,i,∗∈ℝmisubscript𝐊𝜅𝑖superscriptℝsubscript𝑚𝑖\mathbf{K}_{\kappa,i,*}\in\mathbb{R}^{m_{i}} is computed using the kernel function kϕκsubscript𝑘subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝜅k_{\bm{\phi}_{\kappa}} between the feature matrix 𝐗isubscript𝐗𝑖\mathbf{X}_{i} and the test features 𝐱∗subscript𝐱\mathbf{x}_{*}.

The determinant term is commonly viewed as a complexity penalty for the kernel [Rasmussen and Williams, 2005]. However, recent findings in Rothfuss et al. [2021] suggest that this form of complexity regularization may be inadequate when dealing with expressive kernels that possess numerous hyperparameters, such as deep kernels. Furthermore, there is no complexity penalty imposed on the prior mean, which can lead to a higher risk of overfitting. In PAC-PFL, we address these limitations by using (9) as the loss function, which includes a KL divergence term between the hyper-posterior and the hyper-prior. The KL term penalizes hyper-posteriors that deviate significantly from the hyper-prior, thereby effectively regularizing both the mean and the kernel of the GP prior.

Computing the predictive posterior.

Given a set of priors Pϕ1,⋯,Pϕksubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ1⋯subscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑘P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}} trained by PAC-PFL, our objective is to compute the predictive posterior at a test point 𝐱∗subscript𝐱\mathbf{x}_{*}. We denote by 𝒬^^𝒬\hat{\mathcal{Q}} a uniform distribution over these priors, which serves as the SVGD approximation to the true optimal hyper-posterior, 𝒬∗superscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}^{*}. By introducing a categorical random variable Z𝑍Z that is distributed uniformly over 1,⋯,k1⋯𝑘{1,\cdots,k} and denotes which of the priors Pϕ1,⋯,Pϕksubscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ1⋯subscript𝑃subscriptbold-italic-ϕ𝑘P_{\bm{\phi}_{1}},\cdots,P_{\bm{\phi}_{k}} is used for making inference, the predictive posterior can be expressed as follows:

(34)
